question_details.query: How do the effects of creating short versus long flexible habitats on subtidal artificial structures compare for fish and invertebrate populations in Australia?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
The creation of long flexible habitats (>50 mm) on subtidal artificial structures was found in two studies to support macroalgae, non-mobile invertebrates, and fish species that were not present on surfaces without these habitats [3451]. One study on long flexible habitats noted an alteration in the composition of the non-mobile invertebrate community [3451], while two studies on short flexible habitats (1–50 mm) found mixed effects on the composition of both mobile and non-mobile invertebrate communities [3450]. Furthermore, one study indicated that short flexible habitats did not lead to an increase in the species richness of mobile or non-mobile invertebrates [3450].

In terms of population abundance, three studies on short flexible habitats showed mixed effects on the abundance of mobile and non-mobile invertebrates [3450]. Similarly, two out of three studies on long flexible habitats reported mixed effects on the abundance of these invertebrates [3451]. However, one study on long habitats found that they supported a higher combined biomass of macroalgae and invertebrates, primarily mussels, compared to structure surfaces without such habitats [3451]. For fish populations, two studies on long habitats revealed mixed effects on the abundance of fish and seahorses [3451]. A single study on short habitats also noted mixed effects on seahorse abundance [3450]. Finally, one study reported that seahorses used the long flexible habitats created on subtidal artificial structures [3451].
summary_statements: The creation of long flexible habitats (>50 mm) on subtidal artificial structures was found to support macroalgae, non-mobile invertebrates, and fish species that were not present on surfaces without the flexible habitats.
Long flexible habitats altered the composition of the non-mobile invertebrate community.
Short flexible habitats (1–50 mm) had mixed effects on the composition of both mobile and non-mobile invertebrate communities.
Short flexible habitats did not lead to an increase in the species richness of mobile or non-mobile invertebrates.
Short flexible habitats showed mixed effects on the abundance of mobile and non-mobile invertebrates.
Long flexible habitats had mixed effects on the abundance of mobile and non-mobile invertebrates.
Long habitats supported a higher combined biomass of macroalgae and invertebrates, primarily mussels, compared to structure surfaces without such habitats.
For fish populations, long habitats had mixed effects on the abundance of fish and seahorses.
Short habitats had mixed effects on seahorse abundance.
Seahorses used the long flexible habitats created on subtidal artificial structures.

question_details.query: What is the evidence base for the effectiveness of creating large protrusions or ridges (>50 mm) on subtidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: We found no studies that evaluated the effects of creating large protrusions or ridges (>50 mm) on the biodiversity of subtidal artificial structures (3443, 3445). This means there is no evidence to indicate whether the intervention has any desirable or harmful effects (3443, 3445).
summary_statements: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of creating large protrusions or ridges (>50 mm) on the biodiversity of subtidal artificial structures.
There is no evidence to indicate whether creating large protrusions or ridges (>50 mm) on subtidal artificial structures has any desirable or harmful effects.

question_details.query: What are the observed outcomes of transplanting or seeding organisms onto intertidal artificial structures in Australian estuaries?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Studies in Australian estuaries have examined the effects of transplanting or seeding organisms onto intertidal artificial structures (3472). Transplanted oysters were found to support macroalgae, mobile and non-mobile invertebrates, and fish species that were absent on structures without oysters (3472). However, the effects on combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and diversity were mixed, depending on the site and the physical characteristics of the structure's surface (3472). In one study, transplanting oysters increased mobile invertebrate species richness (3472). Conversely, transplanting oysters or coralline algae did not lead to an increase in fish species richness or abundance in two out of three studies (3472). Similarly, one study found no increase in the combined abundance of macroalgae and invertebrates after transplanting oysters (3472). The survival of invertebrates transplanted onto these structures varied based on the species, site, and the presence of features like grooves and ridges on the surfaces (3472). One study also noted that transplanting oysters did not increase the time fish spent interacting with the surfaces (3472).
summary_statements: Studies in Australian estuaries have examined the effects of transplanting or seeding organisms onto intertidal artificial structures.
Transplanted oysters were found to support macroalgae, mobile and non-mobile invertebrates, and fish species that were absent on structures without oysters.
The effects of transplanting organisms on combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and diversity were mixed.
The mixed effects on species richness and diversity depended on the site and the physical characteristics of the structure's surface.
In one study, transplanting oysters increased mobile invertebrate species richness.
Transplanting oysters or coralline algae did not lead to an increase in fish species richness or abundance in two out of three studies.
One study found no increase in the combined abundance of macroalgae and invertebrates after transplanting oysters.
The survival of invertebrates transplanted onto intertidal artificial structures varied based on the species, the site, and the presence of features like grooves and ridges on the surfaces.
One study noted that transplanting oysters did not increase the time fish spent interacting with the surfaces of the artificial structures.

question_details.query: Which habitat creation methods are most effective for increasing overall species richness and diversity on intertidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the available evidence, creating hole habitats (>50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures is the most effective method for increasing species richness and diversity. Three replicated, controlled studies found that creating hole habitats, along with other features like rock pools or grooves, increased the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species diversity and/or richness on structure surfaces (3467). These habitats also supported species that were absent from structure surfaces without these features (3467). In contrast, creating natural rocky reef topography on intertidal artificial structures did not increase the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness in one study (3435). Furthermore, another study found that creating short flexible habitats (1–50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures decreased the combined macroalgae, invertebrate, and fish species richness (3459).
summary_statements: Creating hole habitats larger than 50 mm on intertidal artificial structures is the most effective method for increasing species richness and diversity.
Creating hole habitats, rock pools, or grooves on intertidal artificial structures increased the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species diversity and/or richness on structure surfaces.
Hole habitats, rock pools, or grooves on intertidal artificial structures supported species that were absent from structure surfaces without these features.
Creating natural rocky reef topography on intertidal artificial structures did not increase the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness.
Creating short flexible habitats between 1 and 50 mm on intertidal artificial structures decreased the combined macroalgae, invertebrate, and fish species richness.

question_details.query: In European marine environments, how do the outcomes of creating textured surfaces on intertidal structures vary?

summary_details.relevant_summary: In European marine environments, creating textured surfaces on intertidal structures has shown varied outcomes. One study in the UK found that creating textured surfaces along with using environmentally-sensitive material had mixed effects on the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness, depending on the texture and site (3466). Two studies in the Netherlands reported that textured surfaces did not increase macroalgal abundance (3466). The effect on invertebrate abundance is also varied: two studies in the UK and the Netherlands found no increase, while one study found mixed effects on barnacle and mobile invertebrate abundances, and another found increased barnacle abundance (3466). Creating natural rocky reef topography on intertidal artificial structures in the UK did not increase combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness (3435). However, it had mixed effects on barnacle and mobile invertebrate abundances depending on the site, and the created topography was colonized by macroalgae and limpets (3435). In conjunction with using environmentally-sensitive materials, creating textures has also shown mixed results. For instance, using ECOncrete™ with grooves, ledges, and holes increased species richness and diversity (3469). Conversely, limestone-cement with pits, grooves, ridges, and texture had mixed effects on richness and diversity depending on the site (3469). Similarly, this combination had mixed effects on mobile invertebrate and barnacle abundance based on the site, wave-exposure, and material type (3469).
summary_statements: In European marine environments, creating textured surfaces on intertidal structures has shown varied outcomes.

In the UK, creating textured surfaces along with using environmentally-sensitive material had mixed effects on the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness, depending on the texture and site.
In the Netherlands, textured surfaces did not increase macroalgal abundance.

In another case, textured surfaces increased barnacle abundance.

Creating natural rocky reef topography on intertidal artificial structures in the UK had mixed effects on barnacle and mobile invertebrate abundances depending on the site.
Topography created to mimic natural rocky reefs on intertidal artificial structures in the UK was colonized by macroalgae and limpets.

Limestone-cement with pits, grooves, ridges, and texture had mixed effects on richness and diversity depending on the site.

question_details.query: What actions can enhance fish communities on subtidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One study in Italy found that subtidal artificial structures with harvesting restrictions had a different fish community composition and higher fish species richness compared to structures without restrictions [3457]. The study also found that the restricted structure supported species absent from the unrestricted ones [3457]. However, another study in Italy reported similar total fish abundance around structures with and without harvesting restrictions, but abundances varied by species and survey date [3457]. One study found higher seabream abundances around the structure with harvesting restrictions [3457]. A study in Italy reported that legally restricting human access to subtidal artificial structures did not prevent people from harvesting invertebrates and fish [3457]. Another study in Japan reported that creating small protrusions on a subtidal artificial structure had mixed effects on macroalgal abundance depending on the species [3453].
summary_statements: A study in Italy found that subtidal artificial structures with harvesting restrictions had a different fish community composition compared to structures without restrictions.
Subtidal artificial structures with harvesting restrictions had higher fish species richness compared to structures without restrictions, according to a study in Italy.
One study found that a subtidal artificial structure with harvesting restrictions supported species that were absent from unrestricted structures.
A study in Italy reported similar total fish abundance around subtidal artificial structures with and without harvesting restrictions.

question_details.query: How do the effects of creating hole habitats versus pit habitats on intertidal artificial structures compare for biodiversity?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Creating hole habitats (>50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures was found in three studies to alter macroalgae and invertebrate community composition and increase species diversity or richness (3467). One study found that these habitats were used by sea slugs, urchins, and octopuses (3467). However, one study reported that creating hole habitats did not increase macroalgal abundance, and another found they did not increase invertebrate abundance (3467).

Creating pit habitats (1–50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures was found in multiple studies to alter the community composition of macroalgae and invertebrates and increase their species richness or diversity (3475). Some studies also reported an increase in fish species richness and abundance (3475). The effects on invertebrate abundance were mixed, with some studies reporting an increase, some no effect, and others mixed results depending on various factors (3475). Most studies looking at macroalgal abundance found that pit habitats did not cause an increase (3475). Pit habitats were reported to be used by periwinkles, macroalgae, and invertebrates (3475).
summary_statements: Creating hole habitats (>50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures alters macroalgae and invertebrate community composition.
Creating hole habitats (>50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures increases species diversity or richness.
Hole habitats on intertidal artificial structures were used by sea slugs, urchins, and octopuses.
Creating hole habitats did not increase macroalgal abundance.
Creating hole habitats did not increase invertebrate abundance.
Creating pit habitats (1–50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures alters the community composition of macroalgae and invertebrates.
Creating pit habitats (1–50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures increases the species richness or diversity of macroalgae and invertebrates.
Creating pit habitats on intertidal artificial structures increases fish species richness and abundance.
The effects of creating pit habitats on invertebrate abundance were mixed.
Pit habitats did not cause an increase in macroalgal abundance.
Pit habitats were used by periwinkles, macroalgae, and invertebrates.

question_details.query: In locations like Israel, the UK and Australia, how do outcomes vary when using environmentally-sensitive materials on subtidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: A controlled study in the English Channel, UK, found that artificial reef modules made of scrap tyres developed a similar sessile invertebrate community composition as traditional artificial concrete modules (2259). In the Mediterranean Sea, Israel, pyramid reefs made of “sea-friendly” concrete developed different invertebrate community compositions compared to reefs of either traditional concrete plinth-pole structures or bundles of traditional concrete tubes (2259). One controlled study in the Mediterranean Sea found that invertebrate species richness was lower on “sea-friendly” pyramid reefs compared to bundle reefs of traditional concrete (2259). Another controlled study in the Mediterranean Sea found that “sea-friendly” concrete pyramids had lower abundance compared to plinth-pole structures after two years, but higher after three (2259). One replicated, controlled study in the Firth of Lorn, UK, found that the complexity of artificial reef modules had mixed effects on the abundance of edible crab and velvet swimming crab (2259). No studies were found that evaluated the effects of using environmentally-sensitive materials on subtidal artificial structures in Australia (2255, 2256, 2259).
summary_statements: A controlled study in the English Channel, UK, found that artificial reef modules made of scrap tyres developed a similar sessile invertebrate community composition as traditional artificial concrete modules.

In the Mediterranean Sea, Israel, pyramid reefs made of “sea-friendly” concrete developed different invertebrate community compositions compared to reefs of either traditional concrete plinth-pole structures or bundles of traditional concrete tubes.

question_details.query: What is the state of evidence for managing human activities, like maintenance and harvesting, on intertidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Two studies examined the effects of managing or restricting harvesting of species on intertidal artificial structures (3458). One replicated, site comparison study in Gibraltar and Spain reported that restricting human access on intertidal artificial structures did not increase the limpet abundance on structure surfaces but resulted in larger limpets with more balanced sex ratios than unrestricted structures (3458). One replicated, randomized study in Italy reported that legally restricting human access on intertidal artificial structures did not prevent people from harvesting invertebrates and fishes on and around structures (3458). No studies were found that evaluated the effects of ceasing or altering maintenance activities on intertidal artificial structures on the biodiversity of those structures (3440). We also found no studies that evaluated the effects of controlling or removing non-native or nuisance species on intertidal artificial structures on the biodiversity of those structures (3439).
summary_statements: Two studies examined the effects of managing or restricting the harvesting of species on intertidal artificial structures.
A study in Gibraltar and Spain reported that restricting human access on intertidal artificial structures did not increase the limpet abundance on structure surfaces.
A study in Gibraltar and Spain reported that restricting human access on intertidal artificial structures resulted in larger limpets with more balanced sex ratios than on unrestricted structures.

No studies were found that evaluated the effects on the biodiversity of intertidal artificial structures from ceasing or altering maintenance activities on those structures.
No studies were found that evaluated the effects on the biodiversity of intertidal artificial structures from controlling or removing non-native or nuisance species on those structures.

question_details.query: What factors influence the survival and growth of canopy algae transplanted onto subtidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The survival of canopy algae transplanted onto subtidal artificial structures has been found to vary depending on the wave-exposure, the surrounding habitat, and the presence and/or mesh size of cages around the transplants (3471). In one study, the surface orientation had no effect on survival (3471). The growth of transplanted canopy algae was found to be dependent on the wave-exposure, surface orientation, and the presence of cages (3471). The mesh size of the cages, however, had no effect on growth in one study (3471). For macroalgae transplanted onto intertidal structures, survival was higher at mid- and high-shores compared to the low-shore (3472), while growth was similar across all shore heights (3472). The abundance of kelp recruits on a subtidal artificial structure was found to vary with the distance from the transplanted kelp individuals and the surface orientation (3471). The cover of transplanted canopy algae was higher when placed under cages, but it decreased or was lower when left uncaged (3471). One study reported that transplanted kelp appeared to reproduce (3471).
summary_statements: The survival of canopy algae transplanted onto subtidal artificial structures has been found to vary depending on the wave-exposure.

question_details.query: To alter the existing ecological community on an intertidal artificial structure, which habitat modifications have been most consistently effective?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One replicated, controlled study in the Netherlands reported that creating long flexible habitats (>50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures altered the combined macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate community composition on the structure's surfaces. The flexible habitats also supported macroalgae, mobile and non-mobile invertebrates that were absent from structure surfaces without the habitats [3460]. In another study, creating short flexible habitats (1-50mm) on intertidal artificial structures was found to alter the combined macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate community, however it had mixed effects on the combined mobile invertebrate and fish community [3459]. Using environmentally-sensitive materials has also been found to alter the ecological community on intertidal artificial structures. Two of four studies found that using hemp-concrete or ECOncreteTM in place of standard-concrete altered the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition. One of these studies also found that using shell-concrete or reduced-pH-concrete did not alter the community composition [3469].
summary_statements: Creating long flexible habitats (greater than 50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures altered the combined macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate community composition on the structure's surfaces.
Long flexible habitats on intertidal artificial structures supported macroalgae, mobile invertebrates, and non-mobile invertebrates that were absent from structure surfaces without the habitats.
Creating short flexible habitats (1-50mm) on intertidal artificial structures was found to alter the combined macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate community.
Creating short flexible habitats (1-50mm) on intertidal artificial structures had mixed effects on the combined mobile invertebrate and fish community.

question_details.query: What is the evidence for creating adjoining cavities or 'swimthrough' habitats on artificial structures, and how does it differ between subtidal and intertidal zones?

summary_details.relevant_summary: For creating large adjoining cavities or 'swimthrough' habitats (>100 mm) on intertidal artificial structures, no studies were found that evaluated the effects on biodiversity [3438]. For small adjoining cavities (≤100 mm) on intertidal artificial structures, two studies were found. One study in South Africa reported no alteration in mobile invertebrate community composition, species richness, or diversity, but an increase in mobile invertebrate abundance on structure surfaces [3468]. A study in the UK and the Netherlands found that varying the size and arrangement of small swimthrough habitats did not increase combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness but did alter invertebrate abundance [3468]. For large adjoining cavities (>100 mm) on subtidal artificial structures, two studies were found. One study in the USA revealed that these habitats supported fish species absent from structure surfaces without them, and led to an increase in overall fish species richness and abundance [3456]. A study in Mayotte reported their use by juvenile spiny lobsters, groupers, sea firs, and adult fishes [3456].
summary_statements: For creating large adjoining cavities or 'swimthrough' habitats (greater than 100 mm) on intertidal artificial structures, no studies were found that evaluated the effects on biodiversity.
Two studies were found for small adjoining cavities (less than or equal to 100 mm) on intertidal artificial structures.
A study in South Africa reported no alteration in mobile invertebrate community composition, species richness, or diversity on intertidal artificial structures with small adjoining cavities.
The study in South Africa did report an increase in mobile invertebrate abundance on the surfaces of intertidal artificial structures with small adjoining cavities.

question_details.query: To improve biodiversity on intertidal artificial structures, how do the outcomes of creating natural rocky reef topography compare to creating 'rock pools'?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Creating natural rocky reef topography on intertidal artificial structures was found in one UK study not to increase the combined species richness of macroalgae and invertebrates (3435). Another UK study observed mixed effects on the abundance of barnacles and mobile invertebrates, but noted that the created topography was colonized by macroalgae and limpets (3435). In contrast, creating 'rock pools' on intertidal artificial structures has been examined in eighteen studies across various locations (3476). Nine out of twelve of these studies found that rock pools supported higher combined species diversity and/or richness of macroalgae, invertebrates, and/or fish compared to surfaces without pools (3476). thirteen studies reported that rock pools supported species that were not present on structure surfaces without pools (3476). However, the effects could be mixed, with three studies finding similar species richness in pools and on structure surfaces (3476). The community composition and species richness in created pools could also be similar or different to natural rock pools (3476). Two studies noted that a variety of marine life used the created rock pools (3476).
summary_statements: A UK study found that creating natural rocky reef topography on intertidal artificial structures did not increase the combined species richness of macroalgae and invertebrates.
Another UK study observed mixed effects on the abundance of barnacles and mobile invertebrates from creating natural rocky reef topography.
The created natural rocky reef topography was colonized by macroalgae and limpets.
The creation of 'rock pools' on intertidal artificial structures has been examined in eighteen studies across various locations.

question_details.query: What interventions can be used to increase algal abundance on marine artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Three studies found that transplanting or seeding organisms onto subtidal artificial structures can affect algal abundance (3471). Two of these studies in Italy and Croatia showed that the cover of canopy algae transplanted onto these structures increased when placed under cages, but decreased when left uncaged (3471). Another study in Japan indicated that the abundance of kelp recruits on a subtidal artificial structure varied depending on the distance from transplanted kelp individuals and the surface orientation (3471). One study also reported that kelp transplanted onto a subtidal artificial structure appeared to reproduce (3471). However, creating textured surfaces of 1 mm or less on intertidal artificial structures was not found to increase macroalgal abundance in two studies conducted in the Netherlands (3466). One study in Australia on creating short flexible habitats (1–50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures reported mixed effects on macroalgal abundance, varying by species group and site (3459).

question_details.query: How do the biodiversity outcomes of creating large hole habitats (>50mm) on artificial structures vary between subtidal zones in Israel and Sweden versus intertidal zones in Australia and Europe?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
In subtidal zones in Israel and Sweden, three studies found that creating large hole habitats on artificial structures altered the community composition and supported species that were not present on surfaces without these features (3434). Two of these studies noted an increase in species richness and/or diversity, while one found no such increase (3434). The effects on the abundance of invertebrates and fish were varied, with some studies showing no increase or mixed results (3434).

For intertidal zones in Australia, the UK, and Israel, three studies revealed that adding large hole habitats increased the species diversity and/or richness of macroalgae and invertebrates (3467). These habitats also supported species that were otherwise absent from the artificial surfaces (3467). However, studies in the Netherlands and Australia indicated that these holes did not increase or had mixed effects on the abundance of invertebrates and macroalgae (3467). One study in Australia also documented the use of these habitats by sea slugs, urchins, and octopuses (3467).

question_details.query: What are the general ecological effects of simultaneously creating grooves and small protrusions, ridges, or ledges on artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Creating grooves and small protrusions, ridges, or ledges on intertidal and subtidal artificial structures has been shown to have various ecological effects. On intertidal structures, these features have altered the macroalgae and invertebrate community composition (3474) and supported species that were not present on surfaces without them (3474). Some studies found an increase in the overall species diversity and/or richness of macroalgae and invertebrates (3474), while others reported mixed effects depending on factors like the site, shore level, and the specific design of the features (3474). For subtidal structures, creating these features, in some cases along with holes and environmentally-sensitive materials, also altered the community composition, supported species that were previously absent, and increased species richness and diversity (3452). However, other studies on subtidal structures found mixed effects on community composition and species richness depending on the orientation of the structure's surfaces (3452). When it comes to species abundance on intertidal structures, studies have reported mixed results. Some found an increase in overall abundance when features were paired with water-retaining covers (3474), while others found no change (3474) or mixed effects (3474). The abundance of invertebrates such as limpets and mussels increased in some cases, while barnacle abundance did not (3465). Fish abundance and richness on intertidal structures generally did not increase with the addition of these features (3474, 3465), but an increase in juvenile salmon feeding activity was observed (3465, 3474). On subtidal structures, the addition of grooves and small protrusions had mixed effects on the abundance of macroalgae and invertebrates (3452). These created habitats were reported to be colonized by various organisms, including microalgal species (3474), macroalgae, and non-mobile invertebrates (3452).
summary_statements: Creating grooves and small protrusions, ridges, or ledges on intertidal and subtidal artificial structures has been shown to have various ecological effects.
On intertidal structures, these features have altered the macroalgae and invertebrate community composition.
On intertidal structures, these features have supported species that were not present on surfaces without them.

question_details.query: When modifying intertidal artificial structures, what factors influence whether invertebrate abundance increases?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One study in Australia found that creating short flexible habitats on intertidal artificial structures had mixed effects on the abundance of non-mobile and mobile invertebrates, depending on the species group and site (3459). Another study in the UK reported that creating natural rocky reef topography on these structures had mixed effects on barnacle and mobile invertebrate abundances, depending on the site (3435). The use of different materials has also been studied. In the UK, using hemp-concrete or shell-concrete in place of standard-concrete was found to increase the combined abundance of macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrates. Hemp-concrete also increased mobile invertebrate species richness, while shell-concrete did not (3469). However, using sandstone instead of basalt or reducing the pH of concrete did not lead to an increase in the abundance of tubeworms, oysters, limpets, barnacles, or combined invertebrates in studies in Australia, the UK, and Ireland. Furthermore, the use of limestone-cement with added textures (pits, grooves, ridges) or altering the composition of concrete had mixed effects on mobile invertebrate and barnacle abundance, depending on the site, wave-exposure, and the specific type of material tested (3469).
summary_statements: Creating short flexible habitats on intertidal artificial structures in Australia had mixed effects on the abundance of non-mobile and mobile invertebrates.
The effect of creating short flexible habitats on intertidal artificial structures on invertebrate abundance depended on the species group and the site.

question_details.query: What is the state of evidence for controlling or removing non-native species on artificial marine structures to benefit biodiversity?

summary_details.relevant_summary: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of controlling or removing non-native or nuisance species on subtidal artificial structures (3441) or on intertidal artificial structures (3439). Additionally, no studies were found that evaluated the effects of ceasing or altering maintenance activities on intertidal artificial structures (3440).

question_details.query: How do the biodiversity outcomes of creating small pits (1-50 mm) versus larger holes (>50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures compare?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Of twenty-two studies that examined the effects of creating pit habitats (1–50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures, four of six replicated, controlled studies found that this altered the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition (3475). Three other replicated, controlled studies, reported that pit habitats supported macroalgae, invertebrate and/or fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without added habitats (3475). Eight of twelve replicated controlled studies found that creating pit habitats on intertidal artificial structures increased the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and/or diversity on structure surfaces (3475). Two of five replicated, controlled studies found that creating pit habitats increased the combined macroalgae and invertebrate abundance on structure surfaces, whilst one study found that creating pits decreased their abundance and one found no effect (3475).

Five studies examined the effects of creating hole habitats (>50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures on the biodiversity of those structures (3467). One replicated, randomized, paired sites, controlled, before-and-after study found that creating hole habitats on an intertidal artificial structure altered the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition on structure surfaces (3467). This study, along with two other replicated, controlled studies also reported that hole habitats supported macroalgae and/or non-mobile invertebrate species that were absent from structure surfaces without added habitat features (3467). Three replicated, controlled studies found that creating hole habitats on intertidal artificial structures increased the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species diversity and/or richness on structure surfaces (3467). One of two replicated, controlled studies reported that creating hole habitats on an intertidal artificial structure did not increase the invertebrate abundance on structure surfaces, and one study found that creating holes had mixed effects on the limpet abundance, depending on the shore level and site (3467). One study reported that hole habitats created on an intertidal artificial structure, along with rock pools, were used by sea slugs, urchins and octopuses (3467).

question_details.query: What interventions have been shown to alter the overall community composition of organisms on subtidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One study found that creating groove habitats and small ledges on a subtidal artificial structure, along with holes and environmentally-sensitive material, altered the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition on structure surfaces (3452). Another study found that creating short flexible habitats on subtidal artificial structures altered the non-mobile invertebrate community composition (3450). However, one study found that reducing the frequency of cleaning on subtidal artificial structures did not alter the combined invertebrate and fish community composition on and around structure surfaces (3447). Additionally, creating grooves and small protrusions (3452) or short flexible habitats (3450) on subtidal artificial structures had mixed effects on the community composition.

question_details.query: In what ways do the reported outcomes of creating natural rocky reef topography on artificial structures differ between intertidal studies in the UK and subtidal studies in Italy?

summary_details.relevant_summary: In the UK, creating natural rocky reef topography on intertidal artificial structures did not lead to an increase in the combined species richness of macroalgae and invertebrates (3435). However, it did have mixed effects on the abundance of barnacles and mobile invertebrates (3435). The artificial topography was also observed to be colonized by macroalgae and limpets, with limpets utilizing the shaded grooves and water-retaining features (3435). In contrast, a study in Italy on subtidal artificial structures found that creating natural rocky reef topography did not result in an increase in the abundance of juvenile canopy macroalgae that settled on the surfaces (3446).
summary_statements: In the UK, creating natural rocky reef topography on intertidal artificial structures did not lead to an increase in the combined species richness of macroalgae and invertebrates.

question_details.query: What are the observed effects on invertebrate abundance when using environmentally-sensitive materials on artificial marine structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: A replicated, randomized, controlled study in the UK found that using hemp-concrete or shell-concrete in place of standard-concrete on intertidal artificial structures increased the combined macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate abundance on the surfaces of the structures (3469). The same study found that the use of hemp-concrete also increased the mobile invertebrate species richness on the surfaces of the structures, but that the use of shell-concrete did not (3469). Two of four replicated, controlled studies in Australia, the UK, Singapore and Ireland found that using sandstone in place of basalt or reducing the pH of concrete on intertidal artificial structures did not increase the abundance of tubeworms, oysters, limpets, barnacles and/or combined invertebrates on the surfaces of the structures (3469). Two other studies found that using limestone-cement, along with creating pits, grooves, small ridges and texture, or altering the composition of concrete had mixed effects on the mobile invertebrate and/or barnacle abundance, depending on the site, wave-exposure and/or the type of material tested (3469).

question_details.query: Which interventions have most consistently increased invertebrate abundance on intertidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Two studies in the USA and the UK found that creating large ledges or ridges on intertidal artificial structures, along with other features, led to an increase in the abundance of mussels or limpets, but not barnacles (3465). One of these studies also reported an increase in the combined abundance of macroalgae, microalgae, and invertebrates on the structure surfaces (3465). Another study in Australia reported that creating short flexible habitats on these structures had mixed effects on the abundance of non-mobile and mobile invertebrates, depending on the species and site (3459). This study also found that these habitats did not increase the combined abundance of mobile invertebrates and fish (3459). When considering the use of different materials, two of four studies found that using sandstone instead of basalt or reducing the pH of concrete did not increase the abundance of various invertebrates, including tubeworms, oysters, limpets, barnacles, or combined invertebrates (3469). However, one study in the UK discovered that using hemp-concrete or shell-concrete instead of standard concrete increased the combined abundance of macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrates (3469). The same study also found that while hemp-concrete increased the species richness of mobile invertebrates, shell-concrete did not (3469). Other studies on material composition showed mixed effects on invertebrate abundance depending on the site, wave-exposure, and the type of material used (3469).

question_details.query: What is the evidence for the effects of ceasing or altering maintenance activities on artificial marine structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of ceasing or altering maintenance on intertidal artificial structures (3440). For subtidal artificial structures, one study found that reducing the frequency of cleaning did not alter the invertebrate and fish community, combined abundance, or richness, but did increase macroalgal abundance. It also did not increase the survival or growth of transplanted oysters (3447). A second study found that reducing the area cleaned on a subtidal artificial structure increased seahorse abundance (3447).
summary_statements: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of ceasing or altering maintenance on intertidal artificial structures.

question_details.query: What is the state of evidence for controlling or removing non-native species to enhance biodiversity on marine artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: No studies were found that assessed the effects of controlling or removing non-native or nuisance species on the biodiversity of intertidal artificial structures (3439). This means there is no evidence to show whether this action has positive or negative effects (3439). Likewise, no studies were discovered that assessed the impact of controlling or removing non-native or nuisance species from subtidal artificial structures on the biodiversity of those structures (3441). As a result, there is no evidence to suggest whether the intervention is beneficial or detrimental (3441).
summary_statements: No studies were found that assessed the effects of controlling or removing non-native or nuisance species on the biodiversity of intertidal artificial structures.

question_details.query: How do the biodiversity outcomes of creating small versus large protrusions, ridges or ledges on intertidal artificial structures compare?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Creating large ledges (>50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures, in conjunction with grooves and small protrusions, was found in one of two studies to increase the combined macroalgae, microalgae, and invertebrate species diversity. However, a separate study reported that creating large ridges along with large protrusions did not lead to an increase in the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness [3465]. In contrast, for small ridges or ledges (1–50 mm), one of two studies found no increase in combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness [3464]. Furthermore, two studies revealed that small ridges or ledges supported lower species richness compared to the grooves created between them [3464].

Regarding population abundance, creating large ledges with grooves and small protrusions was shown to increase the combined abundance of macroalgae, microalgae, and invertebrates in one study. Two studies also found that creating large ledges or ridges with other features increased the abundance of mussels or limpets, but not barnacles [3465]. For small ridges or ledges, one of two studies found no increase in the combined macroalgae and invertebrate abundance, and another study noted they supported lower mobile invertebrate and oyster abundances than the grooves between them [3464]. When small protrusions, ridges, or ledges were created along with grooves, the effects on combined species richness and diversity were mixed, with some studies showing an increase and others showing mixed effects depending on factors like depth, height, shore level, and location [3474]. Similarly, the impact on the abundance of invertebrates was also mixed under these conditions [3474]. One study reported that creating large ledges along with grooves and small protrusions increased the feeding activity of juvenile salmon [3465].
summary_statements: Creating large ledges (>50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures, in conjunction with grooves and small protrusions, was found in one of two studies to increase the combined macroalgae, microalgae, and invertebrate species diversity.
A separate study reported that creating large ridges along with large protrusions did not lead to an increase in the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness.

summary_details.relevant_summary: One study in Australia found that creating short flexible habitats on intertidal artificial structures altered the combined macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate community composition (3459). question_details.query: What is the evidence for the effectiveness of reducing the slope of marine artificial structures for biodiversity?

summary_details.relevant_summary: For intertidal structures, one study in an Australian estuary found that reducing the slope, in combination with creating rock pools, led to an increase in the total number of macroalgae, invertebrate, and fish species (3461). However, another study in Australia reported that reducing the slope of an intertidal artificial structure did not result in a greater abundance of macroalgae, oysters, or mobile invertebrates (3461). There were no studies found that assessed the effects of reducing the slope of subtidal artificial structures on biodiversity (3442).
summary_statements: A study in an Australian estuary found that reducing the slope of intertidal structures, in combination with creating rock pools, led to an increase in the total number of macroalgae, invertebrate, and fish species.

question_details.query: When creating flexible habitats on subtidal artificial structures, what are the comparative effects of using short versus long materials?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Five studies assessed the effects of long flexible habitats on subtidal artificial structures, while three studies focused on short flexible habitats (3451, 3450). Long habitats were found to support macroalgae, non-mobile invertebrates, and fish species that were not present on surfaces without these habitats (3451). In contrast, short habitats showed mixed effects on the composition of mobile and non-mobile invertebrate communities (3450). One study on long habitats reported an alteration in the non-mobile invertebrate community (3451), and a similar effect was noted for short habitats in one of two studies (3450). For fish richness and diversity, long habitats had varied effects, dependent on the presence of fish when the habitats were created (3451). For invertebrates, one study on short habitats showed no increase in species richness (3450).

When considering abundance, long habitats were reported in one study to support a higher combined biomass of macroalgae and invertebrates compared to surfaces without flexible habitats (3451). Both long and short habitats had mixed effects on invertebrate abundance, with outcomes varying by species, survey week, and habitat length or density (3451, 3450). For fish, long habitats had mixed effects on abundance, depending on the species and the timing of habitat creation (3451). Similarly, short habitats showed mixed effects on seahorse abundance (3450). In terms of behavior, one study noted that long flexible habitats were used by seahorses (3451). There were no behavioral studies reported for short flexible habitats (3450).

question_details.query: What interventions have been studied in Singaporean waters to enhance intertidal artificial structures, and what were their outcomes?

summary_details.relevant_summary: No studies were found that evaluated interventions to enhance intertidal artificial structures in Singaporean waters (3439). However, studies in other locations have examined several interventions. In Australia, reducing the slope of an intertidal artificial structure, along with creating rock pools, was found to increase the combined macroalgae, invertebrate, and fish species richness (3461). In the UK and Australia, creating large protrusions (>50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures supported mobile and non-mobile invertebrate species that were absent from surfaces without protrusions and increased limpet abundance but did not increase the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness (3463). In Gibraltar and Spain, restricting human access on intertidal artificial structures resulted in larger limpets with more balanced sex ratios but did not increase limpet abundance (3458). Another study in Australia found that creating short flexible habitats (1-50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures altered the community composition of macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrates and had mixed effects on mobile invertebrates and fish, but decreased the overall species richness during low tide (3459). Lastly, no studies were found that evaluated the effects of controlling or removing non-native or nuisance species on intertidal artificial structures (3439).

question_details.query: What is the state of evidence for creating 'swimthrough' habitats on marine artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The effects of creating swimthrough habitats on artificial structures have been investigated in both subtidal and intertidal environments. For subtidal structures, creating small swimthroughs (≤100 mm) has shown mixed effects on juvenile fish communities, with some studies finding no change in community composition or richness, while others noted the presence of species not found on structures without swimthroughs (3436). The impact on juvenile fish abundance was also species, site, and month-dependent (3436). However, these small swimthroughs were observed to be used by a variety of marine life, including juvenile spiny lobsters, sea firs, and both adult and juvenile fish (3436). For large swimthroughs (>100 mm) on subtidal structures, studies have reported an increase in overall fish species richness and abundance, although these effects varied with fish size, species, and time of year (3456). These larger habitats also supported fish species not present on unmodified structures and were used by juvenile spiny lobsters, groupers, sea firs, and adult fish (3456). In the intertidal zone, the creation of small swimthroughs (≤100 mm) did not significantly alter mobile invertebrate community composition, richness, or diversity in one study (3468). However, it was found to increase the abundance of mobile invertebrates in one study, while another found that varying the size and arrangement of these habitats altered invertebrate abundance (3468). Another study found that modifying the size and arrangement of these small swimthroughs did not lead to an increase in the combined species richness of macroalgae and invertebrates (3468).
summary_statements: The effects of creating swimthrough habitats on artificial structures have been investigated in both subtidal and intertidal environments.
For subtidal structures, creating small swimthroughs (less than or equal to 100 mm) has shown mixed effects on juvenile fish communities.
Some studies found no change in juvenile fish community composition or richness on subtidal structures with small swimthroughs.
Other studies noted the presence of fish species on structures with small swimthroughs that were not found on structures without swimthroughs.
The impact of small swimthroughs on juvenile fish abundance was dependent on the species, site, and month.
Small swimthroughs were observed to be used by a variety of marine life, including juvenile spiny lobsters, sea firs, and both adult and juvenile fish.
For large swimthroughs (greater than 100 mm) on subtidal structures, studies have reported an increase in overall fish species richness and abundance.
The effects of large swimthroughs on fish species richness and abundance varied with fish size, species, and time of year.
Large swimthrough habitats on subtidal structures supported fish species not present on unmodified structures.
Large swimthroughs on subtidal structures were used by juvenile spiny lobsters, groupers, sea firs, and adult fish.

In the intertidal zone, one study found that the creation of small swimthroughs (less than or equal to 100 mm) did not significantly alter mobile invertebrate community composition, richness, or diversity.
The creation of small swimthroughs was found to increase the abundance of mobile invertebrates in one study.
Another study found that varying the size and arrangement of small swimthrough habitats altered invertebrate abundance.
One study found that modifying the size and arrangement of small swimthroughs did not lead to an increase in the combined species richness of macroalgae and invertebrates.

question_details.query: What interventions have been shown to alter the community composition of both macroalgae and invertebrates on subtidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Using shell-concrete or quarried rock instead of standard-concrete on subtidal artificial structures, or using ECOncreteTM instead of standard-concrete or fibreglass, in addition to creating texture, grooves, holes, pits, and/or small ledges, was found in six out of eleven studies to alter the composition of the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community on the surfaces of the structures (3470). However, three studies found that using quarried rock or blast-furnace-cement-concrete instead of standard-concrete did not alter the community composition (3470). In one of two studies, creating groove habitats and small ledges on a subtidal artificial structure, along with holes and environmentally-sensitive material, changed the composition of the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community on the structure's surfaces (3452). In two out of three studies, creating textured surfaces on subtidal artificial structures, with one study also using environmentally-sensitive material, altered the composition of the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community on the surfaces of the structures (3449).
summary_statements: Using shell-concrete or quarried rock instead of standard-concrete on subtidal artificial structures was found in six out of eleven studies to alter the composition of the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community on the surfaces of the structures.

Using ECOncreteTM instead of standard-concrete or fibreglass on subtidal artificial structures was found in six out of eleven studies to alter the composition of the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community on the surfaces of the structures.

Creating texture, grooves, holes, pits, and/or small ledges on subtidal artificial structures was found in six out of eleven studies to alter the composition of the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community on the surfaces of the structures.
Three studies found that using quarried rock instead of standard-concrete did not alter the community composition of macroalgae and invertebrates.
Three studies found that using blast-furnace-cement-concrete instead of standard-concrete did not alter the community composition of macroalgae and invertebrates.

In one of two studies, creating groove habitats, small ledges, holes, and using environmentally-sensitive material on a subtidal artificial structure changed the composition of the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community on the structure's surfaces.

In two out of three studies, creating textured surfaces on subtidal artificial structures altered the composition of the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community on the surfaces of the structures.

One study that created textured surfaces on subtidal artificial structures also used environmentally-sensitive material, which resulted in an altered composition of the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community.

question_details.query: In Australian estuaries, what factors influence the effectiveness of transplanting oysters onto intertidal artificial structures for enhancing wider biodiversity?

summary_details.relevant_summary: In Australian estuaries, transplanting oysters onto intertidal artificial structures can support macroalgae, mobile and non-mobile invertebrates, and fish species that are not found on structures without oysters (3472). The effectiveness of this method is influenced by several factors. The combined species richness and diversity of macroalgae and invertebrates are affected by the specific site and the presence and size of grooves, small ridges, or ledges on the artificial surfaces (3472). While transplanting oysters can increase mobile invertebrate species richness, it has been found to not always increase fish species richness or abundance (3472). The survival of transplanted invertebrates, including oysters, varies depending on the species, the site, and the physical characteristics of the structure, such as the presence and size of grooves and ledges (3472). In one study, oyster survival was higher in grooves compared to on ridges (3472). Another study found that transplanting oysters led to an increase in the abundance of non-mobile invertebrates and oyster recruits, while the abundance of barnacles decreased (3472).
summary_statements: In Australian estuaries, transplanting oysters onto intertidal artificial structures can support macroalgae, mobile and non-mobile invertebrates, and fish species.
The species supported by transplanted oysters are not found on structures without oysters.
The effectiveness of transplanting oysters onto intertidal artificial structures is influenced by several factors.
The combined species richness and diversity of macroalgae and invertebrates are affected by the specific site.
The presence and size of grooves, small ridges, or ledges on artificial surfaces affect the combined species richness and diversity of macroalgae and invertebrates.
Transplanting oysters can increase mobile invertebrate species richness.
Transplanting oysters has been found to not always increase fish species richness or abundance.
The survival of transplanted invertebrates, including oysters, varies depending on the species, the site, and the physical characteristics of the structure.
The physical characteristics of an artificial structure, such as the presence and size of grooves and ledges, can affect the survival of transplanted invertebrates.
In one study, oyster survival was higher in grooves compared to on ridges.

question_details.query: In northern Israel, how do the effects of creating pit habitats (1-50 mm) compare with creating hole habitats (>50 mm) on subtidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
In northern Israel, one replicated, controlled study found that creating pit habitats (1-50 mm) on subtidal artificial structures, in conjunction with holes, grooves, and environmentally-sensitive materials, altered the macroalgae and invertebrate community composition and increased their species diversity (3455). These combined features also supported invertebrate and fish species that were not present on structures without them (3455). The study reported mixed effects on the abundance of macroalgae, invertebrates, and fish, depending on the species group (3455).

Similarly, a study in northern Israel on creating hole habitats (>50 mm) found that when combined with grooves and pits, they also altered the community composition of macroalgae and invertebrates and increased species richness and diversity (3434). This combination also supported species absent from structures without these added habitats (3434). Effects on the abundance of algae, invertebrates, and fish were mixed, varying by species group (3434).
summary_statements: In northern Israel, a study found that creating pit habitats (1-50 mm) on subtidal artificial structures, in conjunction with holes, grooves, and environmentally-sensitive materials, altered the macroalgae and invertebrate community composition.

In northern Israel, a study found that creating pit habitats (1-50 mm) on subtidal artificial structures, in conjunction with holes, grooves, and environmentally-sensitive materials, increased the species diversity of macroalgae and invertebrates.
The combined features of pits, holes, grooves, and environmentally-sensitive materials supported invertebrate and fish species that were not present on structures without these features.
A study on creating pit habitats in northern Israel reported mixed effects on the abundance of macroalgae, invertebrates, and fish, depending on the species group.

question_details.query: What interventions are available to increase macroalgal abundance on subtidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One replicated, controlled study in Israel reported that creating hole habitats (>50 mm) on a subtidal artificial structure along with pits, grooves and environmentally-sensitive material had mixed effects on macroalgal abundances on structure surfaces, depending on the species group [3434]. A similar study also in Israel found that creating pit habitats (1–50 mm) on a subtidal artificial structure, along with holes, grooves and environmentally-sensitive material, had mixed effects on macroalgal abundances on structure surfaces, depending on the species group [3455]. In this study, creating pit habitats along with other interventions increased the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species diversity on structure surfaces [3455]. In three studies in Israel and Sweden, creating hole habitats along with other interventions altered the combined macroalgae and invertebrate or mobile invertebrate and fish community composition on and around structures [3434]. Two of these three studies also found that creating hole habitats along with other interventions increased the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and/or diversity [3434].
summary_statements: A replicated, controlled study in Israel reported that creating hole habitats (>50 mm) on a subtidal artificial structure along with pits, grooves and environmentally-sensitive material had mixed effects on macroalgal abundances on structure surfaces.
The effect on macroalgal abundances from creating habitats on subtidal artificial structures depended on the species group.

A study in Israel found that creating pit habitats (1–50 mm) on a subtidal artificial structure, along with holes, grooves and environmentally-sensitive material, had mixed effects on macroalgal abundances.
Creating pit habitats along with other interventions increased the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species diversity on the surfaces of subtidal artificial structures.
In studies in Israel and Sweden, creating hole habitats along with other interventions altered the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition on and around structures.
Studies in Israel and Sweden found that creating hole habitats with other interventions altered the mobile invertebrate and fish community composition on and around structures.

question_details.query: What are the effects of creating flexible habitats on the biodiversity of intertidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One study in the Netherlands reported that creating long flexible habitats (>50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures altered the combined macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate community composition on the structure's surfaces. The flexible habitats also supported macroalgae, mobile and non-mobile invertebrates that were absent from structure surfaces without the habitats (3460). A study in Australia found that creating short flexible habitats (1–50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures also altered the combined macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate community composition. However, it had mixed effects on the combined mobile invertebrate and fish community composition on and around structure surfaces during low tide, and no effect on the mobile invertebrate and fish community during high tide (3459). The same study found that creating short flexible habitats decreased the combined macroalgae, invertebrate and fish species richness on and around structure surfaces during low tide, and had mixed effects on the mobile invertebrate species richness on and around structure surfaces during high tide (3459). It did not increase the fish species richness during high tide (3459).
summary_statements: Creating long flexible habitats (>50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures altered the combined macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate community composition on the structure's surfaces.
Long flexible habitats on intertidal artificial structures supported macroalgae that were absent from structure surfaces without the habitats.
Long flexible habitats on intertidal artificial structures supported mobile and non-mobile invertebrates that were absent from structure surfaces without the habitats.
Creating short flexible habitats (1–50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures altered the combined macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate community composition.
Creating short flexible habitats had mixed effects on the combined mobile invertebrate and fish community composition on and around structure surfaces during low tide.
Creating short flexible habitats had no effect on the mobile invertebrate and fish community during high tide.
Creating short flexible habitats decreased the combined macroalgae, invertebrate and fish species richness on and around structure surfaces during low tide.
Creating short flexible habitats had mixed effects on the mobile invertebrate species richness on and around structure surfaces during high tide.
Creating short flexible habitats did not increase the fish species richness during high tide.

question_details.query: How do the biodiversity outcomes of creating 'rock pools' on intertidal artificial structures vary by location?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Eighteen studies into the creation of ‘rock pools’ on intertidal artificial structures have taken place in various locations, including estuaries in Australia, the UK, and the eastern USA; open coastlines in the UK, Ireland, and southeast Spain; straits in the UK and Malaysia; and a marina in Australia (3476). In thirteen studies across Australia, the UK, the USA, Spain, and Malaysia, it was found that created rock pools supported macroalgae, mobile and non-mobile invertebrates, and fish species that were absent from the surfaces of the structures (3476). However, one study in Australia showed mixed effects on community composition depending on the depth of the pool, the shore level and the site (3476). Another study in Ireland revealed that shore level and wave-exposure influenced community composition, and pools that were sheltered from waves filled with sediment within a two-year timeframe (3476). Nine out of twelve studies in Australia, the UK, Spain, and Malaysia indicated that the creation of rock pools led to a higher diversity and/or richness of combined macroalgae, invertebrate, and/or fish species compared to structure surfaces without pools (3476). In contrast, a study in Australia reported that adding short flexible habitats into the pools had mixed effects on the abundance of macroalgae, invertebrates and fish, with outcomes varying by species group and site (3476).
summary_statements: Eighteen studies into the creation of ‘rock pools’ on intertidal artificial structures have taken place in various locations.
Studies on creating rock pools have occurred in estuaries in Australia, the UK, and the eastern USA.
Studies on creating rock pools have occurred on open coastlines in the UK, Ireland, and southeast Spain.
Studies on creating rock pools have occurred in straits in the UK and Malaysia, and in a marina in Australia.
In thirteen studies across Australia, the UK, the USA, Spain, and Malaysia, created rock pools were found to support macroalgae, mobile and non-mobile invertebrates, and fish species.
The species supported by created rock pools were absent from the surfaces of the artificial structures.
One study in Australia showed that created rock pools had mixed effects on community composition.
The mixed effects on community composition in the Australian study depended on the depth of the pool, the shore level, and the site.
A study in Ireland revealed that shore level and wave-exposure influenced the community composition of created rock pools.
A study in Ireland found that created rock pools that were sheltered from waves filled with sediment within a two-year timeframe.

Nine out of twelve studies in Australia, the UK, Spain, and Malaysia indicated that the creation of rock pools led to a higher diversity and/or richness of species compared to structure surfaces without pools.
The higher diversity and/or richness was observed for combined macroalgae, invertebrate, and/or fish species.
A study in Australia reported that adding short flexible habitats into created rock pools had mixed effects on the abundance of macroalgae, invertebrates and fish.

question_details.query: How do the biodiversity outcomes of creating short flexible habitats compare with long flexible habitats on subtidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Five studies assessed the impact of long flexible habitats on subtidal artificial structures, while three studies focused on short flexible habitats (3451, 3450). Long flexible habitats supported macroalgae, non-mobile invertebrates, and fish species that were not present on structures without these habitats (3451). Short flexible habitats showed mixed results on invertebrate community composition, depending on habitat density, length, and location, and in one study, they did not increase invertebrate species richness (3450). For invertebrates, long flexible habitats had varied effects on abundance depending on species, survey timing, and habitat characteristics, with one study noting a decrease in mussel abundance on the structure but an increase in biomass (mostly mussels) on the flexible habitats themselves (3451). Short flexible habitats also had mixed effects on invertebrate abundance, varying with survey week, species, habitat length, and location (3450). In terms of fish, long flexible habitats had inconsistent effects on fish and seahorse abundance and species richness, influenced by factors like the timing of habitat creation and survey week (3451). Short flexible habitats also showed mixed results on seahorse abundance, depending on the survey week (3450). Additionally, one study reported that seahorses used the long flexible habitats (3451).
summary_statements: Five studies assessed the impact of long flexible habitats on subtidal artificial structures.
Three studies focused on short flexible habitats.
Long flexible habitats supported macroalgae, non-mobile invertebrates, and fish species that were not present on structures without long flexible habitats.
Short flexible habitats showed mixed results on invertebrate community composition, depending on habitat density, length, and location.
In one study, short flexible habitats did not increase invertebrate species richness.
For invertebrates, long flexible habitats had varied effects on abundance depending on species, survey timing, and habitat characteristics.
One study noted a decrease in mussel abundance on the structure but an increase in biomass on the flexible habitats themselves.

question_details.query: What actions can be taken to increase species richness on intertidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Eight of twelve replicated controlled studies found that creating pit habitats (1–50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures increased the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and/or diversity on the surfaces (3475). One study also reported that creating pits increased macroalgal species richness (3475). In one study, creating pits increased limpet and periwinkle species richness (3475). One study found that creating pits and grooves increased fish species richness (3475). However, two studies found that creating pits did not increase species richness, and two other studies found mixed effects (3475).

Three of six replicated controlled studies found that creating groove habitats (1–50 mm) on intertidal artificial structures increased the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and/or diversity on the surfaces (3473). Two studies found that creating grooves did not increase species richness, and one found mixed effects (3473). Two studies found that creating grooves did not increase the species richness of mobile or non-mobile invertebrates (3473). One study found that creating grooves, along with pits, increased fish species richness (3473).
summary_statements: Eight of twelve replicated controlled studies found that creating pit habitats on intertidal artificial structures increased the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and/or diversity on the surfaces.
One study reported that creating pits on intertidal artificial structures increased macroalgal species richness.
In one study, creating pits on intertidal artificial structures increased limpet and periwinkle species richness.
One study found that creating pits and grooves on intertidal artificial structures increased fish species richness.

Two other studies found mixed effects on species richness from creating pits on intertidal artificial structures.

question_details.query: What is the evidence for enhancing biodiversity on subtidal artificial structures by creating depressions like pits, holes, grooves, or crevices?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One of two replicated, randomized, controlled studies in Israel and the UK found that creating groove habitats and small ledges on a subtidal artificial structure, along with holes and environmentally-sensitive material, altered the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition and supported non-mobile invertebrate species that were absent from structure surfaces without added habitat features (3452). The same study found that these features increased the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and diversity on structure surfaces (3452). However, the other study found that creating grooves and small protrusions had mixed effects on the community composition and species richness, depending on the orientation of structure surfaces, and did not increase species diversity (3452). One replicated, randomized, controlled study in the UK found that creating groove habitats and small protrusions on subtidal artificial structures had mixed effects on the combined macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate abundance, depending on the orientation of structure surfaces (3452). Another replicated study in Spain reported that groove habitats and small protrusions created on subtidal artificial structures were colonized by macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrates (3452). One controlled study in Japan reported that creating small protrusions on a subtidal artificial structure had mixed effects on the macroalgal abundance on structure surfaces, depending on the species (3453). There were no studies found that evaluated the effects of creating crevice habitats on subtidal artificial structures on the biodiversity of those structures (3454).
summary_statements: One study in Israel and the UK found that creating groove habitats, small ledges, and holes with environmentally-sensitive material on a subtidal artificial structure altered the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition.

The same study in Israel and the UK found that creating groove habitats, small ledges, and holes on a subtidal artificial structure supported non-mobile invertebrate species that were absent from structure surfaces without added habitat features.

Creating groove habitats, small ledges, and holes on subtidal artificial structures was found in one study to increase the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and diversity on the structures' surfaces.
Another study found that creating grooves and small protrusions had mixed effects on community composition and species richness, depending on the orientation of the structure's surfaces.
The same study that found mixed effects on community composition also found that creating grooves and small protrusions did not increase species diversity.

A replicated, randomized, controlled study in the UK found that creating groove habitats and small protrusions on subtidal artificial structures had mixed effects on the combined macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate abundance, depending on the orientation of the structure's surfaces.
A replicated study in Spain reported that groove habitats and small protrusions created on subtidal artificial structures were colonized by macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrates.
