question_details.query: What biodiversity outcomes have been observed from interventions on intertidal artificial structures in Australian estuaries?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Interventions on intertidal artificial structures in Australian estuaries have shown varied biodiversity outcomes. Transplanting oysters has been found to support macroalgae, mobile invertebrates, non-mobile invertebrates, and fish species that were not present on surfaces without the transplanted oysters (3472). However, the effect of transplanting oysters on combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and diversity is mixed, depending on the site and other physical characteristics of the structures (3472). While transplanting oysters was found to increase mobile invertebrate species richness, it did not increase fish species richness or abundance in most cases studied (3472). Creating hole habitats on these structures, in conjunction with other features like rock pools or grooves, has been shown to alter the overall community composition and support macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate species that were absent from surfaces without these features (3467). This creation of habitats also led to an increase in the combined macroalgae and invertebrate species diversity and richness (3467). However, creating hole habitats did not increase macroalgal or invertebrate abundance in some studies, though the holes were used by sea slugs, urchins, and octopuses (3467). In one study, reducing the slope of an intertidal artificial structure, along with creating rock pools, increased the combined macroalgae, invertebrate, and fish species richness on the structure (3461). However, reducing the slope did not lead to an increase in the abundance of macroalgae, oysters, or mobile invertebrates (3461).
summary_statements: Interventions on intertidal artificial structures in Australian estuaries have shown varied biodiversity outcomes.
Transplanting oysters has been found to support macroalgae, mobile invertebrates, non-mobile invertebrates, and fish species that were not present on surfaces without the transplanted oysters.

question_details.query: What are the effects of creating protrusions, ridges, or ledges on mobile invertebrate abundance on artificial marine structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One replicated study in Australia discovered that creating small ledges on intertidal artificial structures resulted in a lower mobile invertebrate abundance and species richness when compared to the grooves positioned between them (3464). In contrast, another study revealed that the introduction of grooves and small ledges enhanced the richness of mobile invertebrate species (3474). However, a separate study indicated that creating grooves and small ridges had inconsistent impacts on the species richness of mobile and non-mobile invertebrates, with the effects varying based on the size of the grooves and ridges, as well as the specific location (3474). Furthermore, five out of seven replicated, randomized, and controlled studies reported that the creation of groove habitats and small protrusions, ridges, or ledges on intertidal artificial structures produced mixed effects on the abundance of mobile invertebrates. These effects were contingent upon various factors, including the depth and height of the grooves and ridges, the existence of large ledges or water-retaining and light-shading covers, the shore level, and the specific site (3474). Additionally, two studies observed that while the creation of grooves and small ridges or ledges boosted oyster abundance, it did not have the same effect on the abundance of mobile invertebrates (3474).
summary_statements: A replicated study in Australia discovered that creating small ledges on intertidal artificial structures resulted in a lower abundance of mobile invertebrates compared to the grooves between the ledges.

A replicated study in Australia discovered that creating small ledges on intertidal artificial structures resulted in lower species richness of mobile invertebrates compared to the grooves between the ledges.

question_details.query: Which habitat creation interventions most consistently alter community composition on subtidal artificial structures?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One of two replicated, randomized, controlled studies in Israel and the UK found that creating groove habitats and small ledges (1-50mm) on a subtidal artificial structure, along with holes and environmentally-sensitive material, altered the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition on the structure's surfaces (3452). These features also supported non-mobile invertebrate species that were absent from surfaces without added habitat features (3452). A separate study found that creating grooves and small protrusions had mixed effects on community composition, depending on the orientation of the structure's surfaces (3452). One replicated study in Spain reported that groove habitats and small protrusions on subtidal artificial structures were colonized by macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrates (3452). A study of a sunken oil rig in the Mediterranean Sea recorded that at least 53 invertebrate species had colonized the structure after 30 years, including 14 species of molluscs, 14 species of worms, and 11 species of crustaceans (2262). In contrast, a replicated, randomized, controlled study in Italy discovered that creating natural rocky reef topography on subtidal artificial structures did not increase the abundance of juvenile canopy macroalgae that settled onto the structure's surfaces (3446).
summary_statements: Creating groove habitats and small ledges (1-50mm) on a subtidal artificial structure, along with holes and environmentally-sensitive material, altered the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition on the structure's surfaces.

Groove habitats, small ledges, holes, and environmentally-sensitive material on subtidal artificial structures supported non-mobile invertebrate species that were absent from surfaces without added habitat features.
Creating grooves and small protrusions had mixed effects on community composition, depending on the orientation of the structure's surfaces.
Groove habitats and small protrusions on subtidal artificial structures were colonized by macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrates.
A sunken oil rig in the Mediterranean Sea was colonized by at least 53 invertebrate species after 30 years.
The invertebrate species that colonized a sunken oil rig included 14 species of molluscs, 14 species of worms, and 11 species of crustaceans.
Creating natural rocky reef topography on subtidal artificial structures did not increase the abundance of juvenile canopy macroalgae that settled onto the structure's surfaces.
